धर्मक्षेत्रे कुरुक्षेत्रे समवेता युयुत्सवः ।
मामकाः पाण्डवाश्चैव किमकुर्वत सञ्जय ॥

māmakāḥ pāṇḍavāś caiva kim akurvata sañjaya
verses.translation: Dhritarashtra said: O Sanjaya, after gathering on the holy field of Kurukshetra, desiring to fight, what did my sons and the sons of Pandu do?

commentary.dadaji: The very first word of the Geeta is 'Dharmakshetra' — the field of dharma. Dadaji saw this as profoundly significant: Kurukshetra is not merely a battlefield, it is a holy field consecrated through ages of righteous action and pilgrimage. The word 'Mama' (mine) in 'mamakah' reveals Dhritarashtra's attachment — he sees his sons as separate from Pandu's sons, as 'mine' versus 'theirs.' This possessive attachment is the root of all conflict. Dadaji taught that the entire Mahabharata war arose from this single word 'mine' — mine is my family, mine is my kingdom. The Geeta is ultimately the teaching that dissolves this false sense of mine-ness and reveals the One Self in all.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: From the Vedantic perspective, the opening question of the Geeta is deeply symbolic. Kurukshetra — the field of dharma — represents the very field of human consciousness where the eternal battle between the higher and lower nature takes place. Dhritarashtra is physically blind and spiritually blind — he cannot see either the field or the inner nature of events. He must rely on Sanjaya, whose name means 'the totally victorious' — one who has conquered all inner obstacles. The Geeta's teaching unfolds through this narrative frame: the truly blind (attached) must listen carefully to the one whose inner sight is clear.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda interprets this opening verse metaphysically. Dhritarashtra represents the ego-self — blind, attached, unable to witness its own inner battlefield objectively. Kurukshetra is the field of the body and mind. The question 'what did my sons and Pandu's sons do?' represents the eternal inner conflict between the ego-driven faculties (the hundred Kauravas) and the soul-aligned faculties (the five Pandavas). Every human being faces this battlefield daily. The Geeta's teaching is the eternal answer to the ego's confused question.
commentary.goyandka: According to Goyandka's classical analysis, the use of 'Dharmakshetra' to describe Kurukshetra is historically and spiritually precise. Kurukshetra was known from the Vedic age as a sacred pilgrimage site where righteous acts bore multiplied fruit. Dhritarashtra, harboring the hope that the sacred atmosphere might soften his sons' hearts toward dharma, uses this term deliberately. His question to Sanjaya reveals his anxiety — despite possessing divine sight granted by Vyasa, Sanjaya must be questioned, for Dhritarashtra cannot bear to remain in ignorance about the fate of his blind attachment to his sons.

आचार्यमुपसङ्गम्य राजा वचनमब्रवीत् ॥

commentary.dadaji: Duryodhana approaches Drona — his teacher — in a moment of anxiety. This reveals an important truth: even the ego, when threatened, seeks guidance from wisdom. Yet Duryodhana does not approach Drona for knowledge but for reassurance and strategy. He wants to use his teacher's wisdom for selfish ends. Dadaji often pointed out this distinction: approaching a teacher with genuine desire for truth versus approaching for confirmation of one's own views. The latter is not real discipleship.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The verse establishes the contrast between outward seeing and inward understanding. Duryodhana 'sees' the Pandava army — but what does he truly see? He sees only opponents, threats, objects to be overcome. The entire Geeta can be seen as a shift from this limited way of seeing to the divine vision that Krishna eventually grants Arjuna. The movement from duryodhana-vision (seeing only conflict and otherness) to arjuna-vision refined by Krishna's teaching is the Geeta's spiritual journey.
commentary.yogananda: Duryodhana going to his teacher Drona represents the ego consulting the buddhi (higher intellect) in a moment of crisis. But notice — Duryodhana goes to Drona not to ask 'What is truth?' but to bolster his own position. This is the ego using the intellect as a servant of its own agenda. Yoga teaches the opposite: placing the intellect in service of the Self, not the ego. Drona, despite being a great teacher, is on the wrong side of this war — another symbol of how even wisdom can be captured in service of the lower nature.
commentary.goyandka: The grammar of this verse is precise and telling. 'Having seen' (dṛṣṭvā) comes first — Duryodhana acts entirely from seeing, from appearances. He is moved by what he perceives with his outer eyes. The contrast with Dhritarashtra (who cannot see at all) is pointed: Duryodhana can see, but sees only the surface. He approaches his Acharya — his spiritual teacher and preceptor — but approaches him as a king consulting a military advisor, not as a student seeking guidance. This misuse of the teacher-student relationship is itself a form of adharma.

दुर्योधन उवाच ।

व्यूढां द्रुपदपुत्रेण तव शिष्येण धीमता ॥

verses.translation: Duryodhana said: Behold, O Teacher, this mighty army of the sons of Pandu, arrayed by the son of Drupada — your wise disciple.

commentary.dadaji: Duryodhana addresses Drona as 'Acharya' — Teacher — yet his speech is not that of a student. He points out that Dhrishtadyumna, the general of the Pandava forces, is Drona's own disciple. There is a subtle taunt here: your student has turned against you, and his army threatens us. Dadaji noted how worldly people exploit the most sacred relationships — the guru-shishya bond — for political purposes. Duryodhana is planting the seed of insecurity in Drona's mind, hoping to agitate him into fighting harder. This is the language of manipulation dressed as loyalty. True devotion to a teacher is unconditional; Duryodhana's 'respect' is entirely conditional on what Drona can do for him.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Duryodhana's opening word 'paśya' — behold — is charged with irony from the Vedantic standpoint. He commands his teacher to look, but only at the surface — at armies, numbers, formations. The very teacher he addresses is one who possesses the vision of higher knowledge, yet Duryodhana wishes to direct that vision toward the material battlefield alone. This is the fundamental confusion: using extraordinary faculties for ordinary ends. Vedanta reminds us that true seeing — darśana — is not the perception of armies and opponents but the recognition of the One Self in all. Duryodhana can only 'paśya' the army; he cannot see the Ātman.
commentary.yogananda: In the metaphysical interpretation, Duryodhana approaching Drona represents the ego-mind consulting the discriminating faculty in order to strengthen its position rather than transcend it. He says 'behold this mighty army' — the ego catalogues all the forces arrayed against it, not to understand them but to defeat them. Yogananda observed that the ego always takes inventory of its enemies. It measures and calculates. Yet this very measuring is the source of fear. The soul does not count armies; it rests in its own divine nature, unconcerned with the appearance of opposition.
commentary.goyandka: Duryodhana's reference to Dhrishtadyumna as 'tava śiṣyeṇa' — your disciple — is a precise and deliberate political maneuver. Classical commentators like Śrīdhara note that Duryodhana intends to goad Droṇācārya by reminding him that the opposing general was trained by Drona himself. The verse also establishes that the Pandava army, though placed under a disciple of Drona, is nonetheless formidable — described as 'mahatīm camūm,' a great army. The word 'dhīmatā' (wise, intelligent) for Dhrishtadyumna acknowledges his tactical skill even as it implies a challenge to Drona's loyalty.

verses.sanskrit:
अत्र शूरा महेष्वासा भीमार्जुनसमा युधि ।
युयुधानो विराटश्च द्रुपदश्च महारथः ॥

atra śūrā maheṣvāsā bhīmārjuna-samā yudhi
yuyudhāno virāṭaś ca drupadaś ca mahārathaḥ
verses.translation: Here are great heroes, mighty archers, equal in battle to Bhima and Arjuna — Yuyudhana (Satyaki), Virata, and the great chariot-fighter Drupada.

commentary.dadaji: Duryodhana lists the great warriors of the Pandava side, and each name carries a story. These are not strangers — they are family, former allies, beloved figures from childhood. Dadaji would say: look at what attachment to power does. These men who grew up together, who shared the same traditions, the same teachers, the same festivals — now they stand on opposite sides of the field. The tragedy of the Mahabharata is not the battle; it is the rupture of relationship that makes battle necessary. Every great warrior named here represents a bond broken by greed and pride.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Duryodhana compares these warriors to Bhima and Arjuna — the benchmarks of military excellence in his world. This comparison reveals how the ego evaluates everything by comparison, by ranking, by relative strength. 'How do they measure up? Are they equal? Are they greater?' The ego lives in the world of comparison. Vedanta points beyond comparison to the recognition of identity — not 'are they equal to Arjuna?' but 'is not the same Consciousness present in Arjuna and in all these warriors?' Duryodhana's mind, entirely comparative and competitive, cannot conceive of such non-dual recognition.
commentary.yogananda: Each name Duryodhana recites — Yuyudhana, Virata, Drupada — represents a divine quality or force arrayed on the side of righteousness in the inner war. Yogananda saw the Pandava side as representing the soul-aligned faculties: courage, loyalty, dharmic determination. The ego catalogues these qualities with fear, recognizing that they are formidable. The spiritual aspirant who has awakened to the higher forces within also recognizes how powerful the dharmic faculties are — and how they pose the final challenge to the reign of the ego.
commentary.goyandka: This verse begins Duryodhana's enumeration of Pandava commanders. The title 'mahāratha' — great chariot-warrior — has a precise military classification in ancient Indian warfare: a mahāratha could single-handedly fight ten thousand ordinary warriors. Drupada is specifically distinguished with this title. Yuyudhana is another name for Sātyaki, the loyal companion of Krishna. Virāṭa is the king of Matsya in whose court the Pandavas spent their year of incognito exile. The listing serves both narrative and didactic purposes, establishing the scale and quality of the forces at Kurukshetra.

verses.sanskrit:
धृष्टकेतुश्चेकितानः काशिराजश्च वीर्यवान् ।
पुरुजित्कुन्तिभोजश्च शैब्यश्च नरपुङ्गवः ॥
verses.transliteration:
dhṛṣṭaketuś cekitānaḥ kāśirājaś ca vīryavān
purujit kuntibhojaś ca śaibyaś ca nara-puṅgavaḥ
verses.translation: Dhrishtaketu, Chekitana, the valiant king of Kashi, Purujit, Kuntibhoja, and Shaibya — the foremost among men.

Kuntibhoja — king of the Kunti clan, foster-father of Kunti

commentary.dadaji: The names continue — Dhrishtaketu, Kuntibhoja, Shaibya. Kuntibhoja is particularly poignant: he is the foster-father of Kunti herself, the mother of the Pandavas. Here he fights on her sons' side, yet his very presence on the battlefield means he too may die. Dadaji often reflected on how every name in these opening verses of the Geeta represents a human story — a life, a family, a lineage of devotion and love. The Geeta is not abstract philosophy; it begins with the most concrete human reality: the cost of conflict, the weight of relationships, the grief of war.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The title 'nara-puṅgava' — bull among men — applied to Shaibya is a common Sanskrit honorific. From the standpoint of Advaita Vedanta, what is most significant is not who these warriors are individually, but what they represent collectively: a powerful movement of dharma. In the metaphysical reading, when dharma assembles its forces, it calls forth the best in humanity — the brave, the noble, the courageous. The army of dharma is always composed of 'nara-puṅgavas,' those in whom the human spirit reaches its highest expression.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda identified each group of warriors in these opening verses as corresponding to specific faculties, qualities, or forces within the human psyche. The Pandava commanders collectively represent the powers of the soul — integrity, perception, valor in the service of truth. Kuntibhoja, related to Kunti (who represents devotion), and Shaibya (noble loyalty), suggest that the soul's army draws its strength from devotion, faithfulness, and the noble qualities cultivated through spiritual practice.
commentary.goyandka: The enumeration of warriors in these verses follows the classical style of Sanskrit epic poetry called 'nāmāvalī' — a list of names that serves as homage to the heroes. Dhṛṣṭaketu was the son of Śiśupāla, king of Chedī. Cekitāna was a Yadava warrior. Kāśirāja, the king of Kāśī (Varanasi), is described separately as 'vīryavān' — full of valor. This slight emphasis distinguishes him. Purujit and Kuntibhoja were brothers, maternal uncles of the Pandavas. The verse closes with 'nara-puṅgava,' a term of supreme masculine honor in Vedic culture.

verses.sanskrit:
युधामन्युश्च विक्रान्त उत्तमौजाश्च वीर्यवान् ।

commentary.dadaji: The mention of Saubhadra — Abhimanyu, the young son of Arjuna and Subhadra — carries tremendous poignancy for anyone who knows the Mahabharata. Here he is listed among the great warriors, full of promise and valor. Yet Dadaji, knowing the story, saw in this name a symbol of how war destroys the young and the bright. Abhimanyu would die in the most tragic way — trapped in a formation, surrounded by enemies who broke every rule of honorable combat. The mention of his name here, casual and confident, before the storm of war, is heartbreaking. The Geeta speaks to all such Abhimanyus — the young, the gifted, the brave who face life's great battles.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The verse closes with 'sarva eva mahārathāḥ' — all of them, without exception, are great warriors. This universality is spiritually significant. On the side of dharma, every participant is fully qualified, fully capable. Vedanta teaches that when aligned with truth, every faculty of the human being reaches its highest expression. Contrasted with the Kaurava side, which has brilliant individuals but a compromised foundation, the Pandava side has what Advaita would call 'sāmarthya in alignment with the Absolute' — each person functioning as a full expression of their highest nature.
commentary.yogananda: The sons of Draupadi — the Upapandavas — and Abhimanyu represent the next generation of divine forces. In Yogananda's interpretation, they symbolize the fresh spiritual energies that arise through dedicated practice: new powers of discrimination, new capacities of devotion and concentration that emerge as the inner war progresses. They are 'mahārathas' — great warriors — because these freshly cultivated qualities carry enormous power in the inner spiritual battle. Every deepened meditative state, every new insight, strengthens the soul's army with these young, vigorous forces.
commentary.goyandka: Yudhāmanyu and Uttamauja were twin princes in Drupada's army, loyal Pāñcāla commanders. Saubhadra is Abhimanyu — born of Arjuna and Subhadrā (Krishna's sister), trained personally by Arjuna and schooled even in the womb in the secrets of military formation. The Draupadeyāḥ are the five sons of Draupadī by each of the five Pandavas: Prativindhya, Sutasoma, Śrutakīrti, Śatānīka, and Śrutakarman. The concluding epithet 'sarva eva mahārathāḥ' — every single one a great warrior — emphasizes that this is not a partial list but a comprehensive roster of Pandava excellence.

verses.sanskrit:
अस्माकं तु विशिष्टा ये तान्निबोध द्विजोत्तम ।

nāyakā mama sainyasya saṃjñārthaṃ tān bravīmi te
verses.translation: But know also, O best of the twice-born, the distinguished commanders on our side. I name them for your information: the leaders of my army.

commentary.dadaji: After cataloguing the enemy's forces, Duryodhana turns to his own side with the word 'tu' — but, however, on the other hand. This small word reveals the underlying insecurity. He has just described the Pandava army as mighty and filled with warriors equal to Bhima and Arjuna. Now he pivots: 'but on our side there are also distinguished warriors.' He addresses Drona as 'dvijottama' — best of the twice-born — a respectful address. Yet Dadaji noticed that this respect is strategic, not sincere. Duryodhana is trying to reassure himself as much as he is informing Drona. His anxiety drives him to count and recount his own strength.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The phrase 'saṃjñārtham' — for information, for identification — is revealing. Duryodhana frames his listing of commanders as an informational exercise. But why would he need to inform Drona, who knows every warrior on both sides personally? The real audience is Duryodhana himself. He is rehearsing his strengths to manage his own fear. This is the ego's characteristic behavior: when threatened, it lists its assets, counts its resources, catalogs its powers — not to solve the real problem but to temporarily quiet the anxiety. Advaita Vedanta identifies this anxiety as the fundamental mark of a self that has forgotten its infinite nature.
commentary.yogananda: Duryodhana addresses Drona as 'dvijottama' — best of the twice-born. The 'twice-born' refers traditionally to those who have undergone the sacred thread ceremony, a second birth into knowledge and spiritual duty. Yogananda saw deeper meaning: the truly twice-born is one who has had the second birth of spiritual awakening, the entry into Self-knowledge. Duryodhana, addressing Drona with this title, unknowingly identifies the precise quality he himself lacks: he has had the outer birth of nobility, but not the inner birth of wisdom. His enumeration of armies is the activity of the once-born mind.
commentary.goyandka: The conjunction 'tu' (but, however) explicitly signals that Duryodhana is shifting from the opponent's forces to his own. 'Nibodha' — please know, take note — is a polite imperative. Addressing Droṇa as 'dvijottama,' best of the twice-born, acknowledges his Brahmin status and learning while also serving the practical purpose of flattery. The phrase 'mama sainyasya nāyakāḥ' — leaders of my army — is notable: Duryodhana says 'my army,' not 'our army' or 'the Kaurava army.' This proprietary use reveals his psychology: he regards everything, including the army of an entire civilization, as personally his.

commentary.dadaji: Duryodhana lists his own side's great warriors, and it is a formidable list. Bhishma — the greatest living warrior, invincible, the very symbol of dharmic commitment. Drona — the supreme teacher of warfare. Karna — the most generous, most skilled, most tragic figure in the epic, Arjuna's equal and secret brother. Each name here is extraordinary. Dadaji observed that Duryodhana had no shortage of great allies — his failure was not lack of power but lack of wisdom and righteousness. A side can have every advantage and still lose when its foundation is adharma. The Geeta teaches that dharma is the ultimate force.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The list of Kaurava commanders is remarkable for another reason: nearly every one of them privately knew that the Pandavas were in the right. Bhishma knew it. Drona knew it. Even Karna, in his most honest moments, acknowledged it. Yet they fought for the Kaurava side out of obligation, loyalty, debt, and ego. This is the tragedy of noble qualities placed in service of an unworthy cause. Advaita Vedanta would say that their clarity of perception (they saw the truth) was not matched by the freedom to act on that clarity — they were bound by conditioning, by samskāras, by the weight of social obligation.
commentary.yogananda: On the level of inner symbolism, the Kaurava commanders represent formidable ego-forces: Bhishma is the power of unbreakable habit and iron-willed resistance to change; Drona is the crystallized intellectual pattern that has been teaching ego-strategies for years; Karna is the brilliant but misdirected energy, loyal to the wrong master. These forces are powerful precisely because they have been cultivated and trained. The spiritual aspirant who undertakes the inner battle must face exactly these: ancient habits, established mental patterns, and misplaced loyalties that seem noble but serve the ego.
commentary.goyandka: Drona is listed first among the Kaurava commanders — addressed as 'bhavān,' the honorific 'you' — because Duryodhana is speaking directly to him. The epithet for Kṛpa is 'samitiñjaya' — victorious in all assemblies and battles — which is rare; Kṛpa was considered practically invulnerable. Aśvatthāmā, Drona's son, is listed here; his later role in the post-war massacre of the sleeping Pandava camp makes this listing particularly fraught. Saumadatti — Bhūriśravas, grandson of Bāhlika — was a Kuru aristocrat of the highest standing. Each name listed here carries the weight of entire lineages.

commentary.dadaji: The phrase 'mad-arthe tyakta-jīvitāḥ' — who have given up their lives for my sake — reveals Duryodhana's deepest self-perception. He does not say 'for the sake of Hastinapura' or 'for dharma' or 'for the protection of the people.' He says 'for me.' This is pure ego speaking. Dadaji often noted that the greatest violence in human history has been committed not for God, not for truth, not even for nation — but for the aggrandizement of individual ego. 'For my sake' — how much suffering has been created in the world by those three words. The Geeta's teaching is precisely the antidote: act not for 'me' but for the divine will.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The ego's relationship with its followers is clearly expressed in 'mad-arthe tyakta-jīvitāḥ' — they have sacrificed their lives for me. The ego always surrounds itself with those who have given themselves to its cause. And it draws security from this — from the multitude willing to die for it. But Vedanta points out: no amount of external support can remedy the fundamental insecurity of an ego that has forgotten its real nature. Duryodhana's entire speech is a cry of anxiety dressed in the language of strength. He counts warriors as others count beads — hoping the number will equal safety.
commentary.yogananda: These unnamed warriors — 'anye ca bahavaḥ' — represent the vast population of conditioned habits, desires, and impulses that serve the ego without question. Yogananda identified this as the 'army of tendencies' — the countless saṃskāras and vāsanās accumulated over many lifetimes that immediately take the side of the ego when challenged. They are 'yuddha-viśāradāḥ' — battle-hardened — because they have been fighting the soul's freedom for lifetimes. The spiritual seeker recognizes these unnamed forces as the most difficult to overcome: the habits so deeply ingrained that they do not even have individual faces.
commentary.goyandka: This verse serves as a summary conclusion to Duryodhana's enumeration of his own forces. 'Anye ca bahavaḥ śūrāḥ' — and many others who are heroes — acknowledges that his list has been selective, representing only the most distinguished commanders. The comprehensive description follows: they bear diverse weapons (nānā-śastra-praharaṇāḥ) and are all experts in war (yuddha-viśāradāḥ). The phrase 'mad-arthe tyakta-jīvitāḥ' is a warrior's highest praise for his troops — those who have pledged their lives. Commentators note that this phrase, while honorable in a military context, also exposes Duryodhana's proprietary view of the war.

commentary.dadaji: This verse contains one of the most fascinating ambiguities in the entire Geeta. The words 'aparyāptam' and 'paryāptam' each carry two opposite meanings. 'Aparyāptam' can mean 'unlimited, immeasurable' (our army is unlimited — a boast) or 'insufficient, inadequate' (our army is not enough — a fear). Translators have debated this for centuries. Dadaji loved this ambiguity: it perfectly captures Duryodhana's inner state. He is simultaneously boasting and secretly afraid. He says one thing but fears the opposite. This double meaning embedded in the Sanskrit is not accidental — it is the Geeta showing us the nature of the ego: always projecting strength while secretly trembling.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The famous ambiguity of 'aparyāptam' and 'paryāptam' is a gift to the commentator. The verse can be read as Duryodhana's boast: 'Our army protected by Bhishma is limitless; their army protected by Bhima is limited.' Or as his deepest anxiety laid bare: 'Our force is insufficient; their force is more than enough.' Both readings are grammatically valid. Advaita Vedanta would say: the ego always speaks in this double register. Its confident assertions carry the shadow of its deepest fears. The only consciousness that speaks with undivided clarity is the Self — the Ātman that knows no limitation and harbors no secret dread.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda highlighted this verse as a profound psychological portrait. The ego — represented by Duryodhana — is caught between grandiosity and dread. This is the characteristic oscillation of the unenlightened mind: 'I am unlimited!' covers 'I am afraid I am not enough.' The spiritual teaching embedded here is that this oscillation itself, this constant alternation between inflation and deflation, is the mark of ego-consciousness. The soul, established in the Self, knows neither inflation nor deflation. It is 'pūrṇam' — complete — always. The Geeta's entire teaching aims to shift the student from Duryodhana's fearful oscillation to the Ātman's serene fullness.
commentary.goyandka: This verse has generated more commentary than almost any other in the first chapter due to the double meaning of 'aparyāptam' and 'paryāptam.' Śaṅkarācārya, Madhusūdana Sarasvatī, and other major commentators have each chosen different readings. Śrīdhara takes 'aparyāptam' as 'immeasurable/unlimited' and reads the verse as Duryodhana's boast. Others like Keśavakāśmīrin take it as 'insufficient' and read the verse as Duryodhana's private admission of inadequacy to Drona alone. Goyandka's Gita Press commentary follows the reading that sees this as Duryodhana's boast of Kaurava strength, while acknowledging the alternate interpretation.

commentary.dadaji: Duryodhana ends his speech with a military command: protect Bhishma above all others. This reveals how deeply he knows that his entire strategy rests on the invincibility of Bhishma. Without Bhishma standing firm at the center, the Kaurava cause would crumble. Dadaji saw in this a spiritual lesson: when we build our lives on an external foundation — however grand and invincible it may seem — we are always vulnerable. Bhishma could fall. All externals can fall. The only truly indestructible foundation is the Self. The warrior who fights from the center of the Ātman cannot be defeated — for death itself has no power over one established in the Self.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Duryodhana's final instruction is 'protect Bhishma.' In the Vedantic allegory, Bhishma — whose name means 'one of terrible resolve' — represents the power of deeply entrenched conditioned patterns, the ancient vows that bind the individual even against their better judgment. Duryodhana is commanding all his forces to protect these patterns, to keep them intact. This is precisely what the ego does: it marshals all available resources to protect its deepest conditioning, its most fundamental assumptions about itself and reality. The work of Vedanta — of true self-inquiry — is the exact opposite: to examine and dissolve the Bhishmas of our inner life.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda saw in Bhishma the principle of deep karmic obligation — the force of past promises, ancestral duties, and conditioned loyalties that bind the individual to an old order even when wisdom points elsewhere. Duryodhana commands his forces to protect this principle above all else. The ego's deepest instinct is to preserve its oldest patterns. 'Guard the pattern! Guard the habit! Guard what has always been!' The entire spiritual life involves the gradual unwinding of this command — learning to release what was sworn to in past lives and past states of consciousness, and opening to the freedom of the present moment.
commentary.goyandka: The military significance of this command is concrete and precise. 'Ayaneṣu' refers to the various avenues and passages within the battle formation — the flanks, the center, the rear guard. Duryodhana instructs each commander to remain 'yathā-bhāgam' — in his assigned position — while simultaneously focusing all protective attention on Bhishma. This was sound military strategy: Bhishma was the supreme commander and his protection was essential. The Kaurava formation was built around him. Commentators note that this verse, even as military instruction, also reveals Duryodhana's anxiety: he must explicitly command what should be natural to loyal warriors.

commentary.dadaji: With Bhishma's lion-roar and the thunder of his conch, the Geeta's battlefield comes fully alive. Dadaji loved this moment: Bhishma, the oldest, the greatest, the most invincible warrior alive, responds to his grandson's anxiety not with words but with action — a roar, a conch. He is saying: 'Do not fear. I am here.' The sound of the conch was the ancient call to sacred action. In the Vedic tradition, the conch removes fear and announces the presence of divine power. Bhishma's blowing of the conch is an act of compassion toward Duryodhana — whatever his errors, Bhishma will stand by his pledge. This is the complex, heartbreaking loyalty that runs through the entire epic.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The narrative returns from Duryodhana's anxious speech to Sanjaya's external description. We move from the inner world of Duryodhana's fear and calculation back to the outward spectacle: Bhishma roaring like a lion, blowing his conch. Sanjaya describes Bhishma as 'pratāpavān' — the glorious, the blazing. This is the language of awe. Even in describing the Kaurava side, Sanjaya cannot help but use terms of glory. From the Vedantic standpoint, Bhishma's greatness is real — his error is not lack of power but misuse of it, placing extraordinary energy in service of an unworthy cause. This is the tragedy of dharmic power allied with adharma.
commentary.yogananda: The lion's roar of Bhishma represents the deep, primal sound of the ego's ancient fortress announcing its readiness for battle. The conch — the śaṅkha — is a sacred instrument whose sound resonates at a frequency that clears the atmosphere and commands attention. In the inner war, this moment represents the crystallization of resistance: the deepest habits, the oldest patterns, the most entrenched ego-structures announce themselves with full force. This is not merely the beginning of a physical battle but the sounding of the innermost conflict in every human soul — the conflict between the self that must be transcended and the Self that awaits discovery.
commentary.goyandka: The verse marks the formal opening of hostilities. Bhishma is described by three great titles: 'kuru-vṛddhaḥ' (elder of the Kurus), 'pitāmahaḥ' (grandsire — technically great-grandsire of both Pandavas and Kauravas), and 'pratāpavān' (the gloriously powerful). The 'siṃha-nādam' — lion's roar — was a recognized battle cry of the highest warriors, signaling readiness and striking fear in opponents. 'Dadhmau' uses the Sanskrit perfect tense, indicating completed action with present relevance: he blew and the sound is still resonating. This verse triggers the cascading exchange of conch-sounds that fills the next several verses and formally inaugurates the Kurukshetra war.

commentary.dadaji: Bhishma's lone lion-roar has now triggered an avalanche of sound — conches, kettledrums, tabors, drums, cow-horns, all erupting at once. The Kaurava side answers its commander's signal with full-throated enthusiasm. Dadaji often reflected on how quickly the momentum of conflict builds: one action, one declaration, and suddenly the entire force of accumulated hostility is unleashed. The Sanskrit word 'sahasā' — suddenly, all at once — captures this irreversibility. Once certain moments are set in motion, they cannot be recalled. This is why the Geeta begins not in a palace or a forest but here — at this point of no return — because only at this threshold does the urgency of spiritual wisdom become undeniable.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The multiplicity of instruments enumerated — śaṅkhāḥ, bheryaḥ, paṇava, ānaka, go-mukha — represents the cacophony of the restless mind that is not yet stilled by meditation or wisdom. Each instrument is a different voice of distraction, desire, or fear. The resulting 'tumula śabda' — tumultuous sound — is the condition of the ordinary unexamined mind: a roar of competing impulses with no single organizing clarity. Against this background of noise, Krishna will soon speak. The teaching of the Geeta is, in one sense, the voice of wisdom rising above the battlefield's deafening din — the still small voice that reaches those who are ready to hear beneath all the tumult.
commentary.yogananda: The sudden simultaneous sounding of all instruments — 'sahasaiva abhyahanyanta' — represents the moment when the ego's forces mobilize completely. In the inner war, this is the experience of the aspirant who, having made the first decisive commitment to the spiritual path, suddenly finds that all the forces of habit, desire, and distraction rise up simultaneously. It can feel overwhelming. Yogananda reassured his students that this eruption of opposition is itself a sign of progress: the ego only marshals its full army when it senses a genuine threat to its dominion. The 'tumula śabda' — this deafening inner noise — is the darkness before the dawn of inner silence.
commentary.goyandka: This verse describes the sonic response of the Kaurava forces to Bhishma's signal. The five instruments named cover the full spectrum of ancient Indian martial music: śaṅkha (conch, blown wind instrument), bherī (large kettledrum struck with sticks), paṇava (small tabor worn around the neck), ānaka (a large war drum played in pairs), and go-mukha (literally 'cow-mouthed,' a large horn or bugle). Together they represent the full orchestration of a Vedic army's battle preparations. The use of the imperfect passive 'abhyahanyanta' suggests that the sounding was not commanded by anyone specifically — it arose spontaneously from every direction at once, creating the 'tumula śabda,' the tremendous uproar.

commentary.dadaji: The shift from the Kaurava instruments to Krishna and Arjuna is dramatic and deliberate. On one side: a cacophony of military drums and horns signaling fear and aggression. On the other: two figures stationed on a magnificent chariot, white horses gleaming, blowing divine conches. Dadaji always pointed to the white horses as symbolic of purity — Krishna chooses to guide a chariot of pure intention. The word 'divyau' — divine — distinguishes these conches from ordinary military instruments. They are not simply war trumpets; they carry a sacred vibration. Where Bhishma's conch responded to Duryodhana's anxiety, Krishna and Arjuna's conches announce the presence of dharma.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The epithet 'Mādhava' — used here for the first time in the Geeta — is significant. Mādhava derives from 'Madhu,' one of the Yadu ancestors, but is also interpreted as 'lord of Mā (Lakshmi)' — the lord of divine prosperity and grace. Sanjaya names Krishna first, before Arjuna, even though Arjuna is the protagonist. This signals the Geeta's ultimate teaching: the Divine comes first; the individual devotee acts in response to the Divine, not the reverse. The white horses symbolize the pure sāttvic qualities that draw the chariot of spiritual life — the mind purified, refined, capable of bearing the weight of divine instruction.
commentary.yogananda: The great chariot yoked with white horses — śvetair hayair yukte — is one of the most vivid images in all sacred literature. Yogananda saw in it an exact representation of the spiritual anatomy: the chariot is the body, the white horses are the purified life-forces, and stationed within are the individual soul (Arjuna) and the divine Presence (Krishna). The blowing of the divine conches represents the moment the aspiring soul, guided by the inner divine consciousness, announces its readiness to engage the ultimate battle: the battle for liberation. These are not ordinary shells; they carry the primordial sound — Oṃ, the seed of all creation.
commentary.goyandka: This verse introduces a shift in perspective: after describing the Kaurava tumult, Sanjaya now focuses on the Pandava side's most important occupants — Krishna and Arjuna together in their chariot. The chariot is described as 'mahati' (magnificent, great) and 'yukte śvetair hayaiḥ' — yoked with white horses. The white horses were a gift of the gods; they belonged to Arjuna and were called Śaivya, Sugrīva, Meghapuṣpa, and Balāhaka in various accounts. The dual verb 'pradadhmatuḥ' emphasizes that both act simultaneously. The word 'pra' in the prefix intensifies the action — they blew forth with full power.

commentary.dadaji: Each conch has a name, and each name carries a history and a teaching. Pāñcajanya — Krishna's conch — was retrieved from the depths of the ocean after slaying the demon who had kidnapped Sandipani Muni's son. It is a conch born of conquest over darkness. Devadatta — 'given by the gods' — was Arjuna's divine gift. Pauṇḍra, Bhima's mighty conch, matches his thunderous nature. Dadaji loved how the Geeta introduces each warrior through his instrument: the conch is the voice of the warrior's soul, his unique frequency in the symphony of dharma. Krishna's epithet here — Hṛṣīkeśa, Lord of the senses — is profoundly meaningful: the one who controls the senses is the one who blows the first divine note.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The epithet 'Hṛṣīkeśa' — Lord of the senses — is of special importance in Vedantic study of the Geeta. Arjuna will later use this same name when asking Krishna to position the chariot between the armies. It signals that Krishna is the master of all sensory experience, not its slave. The one who leads the Pandava cause and guides the divine chariot is precisely the one who has transcended sensory bondage. This is Vedanta's central prescription: establish yourself as the witness-consciousness that governs the senses rather than being driven by them. Hṛṣīkeśa does not merely fight in this war — He orchestrates it from the level of supreme Self-mastery.
commentary.yogananda: The three conches sounding here — Pāñcajanya, Devadatta, and Pauṇḍra — represent the three principal levels of spiritual calling. Pāñcajanya, retrieved from the depths of the ocean after defeating a demon, represents the calling that emerges from the deepest inner transformation, from victory over the unconscious. Devadatta — given by the gods — represents the calling that is a divine gift, bestowed through grace. Pauṇḍra — mighty, earth-shaking — represents the calling of sheer spiritual will and vital force. Together they announce that the dharmic battle is engaged on all three levels: the depths of the unconscious, the heights of divine grace, and the full force of awakened will.
commentary.goyandka: The three conches named here are among the most famous objects in the Mahābhārata. Pāñcajanya was obtained by Krishna when he slew the demon Pañcajana (or Śaṅkhāsura) who lived in the sea; it is made from that demon's bones. Devadatta was gifted to Arjuna by Varuṇa, the god of waters, when Arjuna won the divine bow Gāṇḍīva. Pauṇḍra (also called Vaiṣṇava) was Bhīma's, known for its tremendous volume. The epithets used are precise: Arjuna as 'Dhanañjaya' (one who won wealth during the Rājasūya sacrifice), Bhīma as 'bhīma-karmā' (doer of terrible deeds) and 'vṛkodara' (wolf-bellied, for his insatiable strength and appetite).

commentary.dadaji: Yudhishthira — the eldest Pandava, the embodiment of dharma itself — blows 'Anantavijaya': endless victory. This is not the boastful claim of a warrior; it is the quiet certainty of one who has lived his entire life in truth. Dadaji saw in this conch-name a profound assurance: the path of righteousness may be difficult, it may pass through exile and humiliation and grief, but its final victory is endless and unassailable. Truth cannot ultimately be defeated. The other Pandavas' conches — Sughosha (sweet-sounding) for the handsome, graceful Nakula; Maṇipuṣpaka (jewel-flowered) for the wise Sahadeva — each reflects the character of its owner.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Yudhishthira is identified here with two designations: 'rājā' (king) and 'kuntī-putraḥ' (son of Kunti). The first establishes his worldly authority; the second, his lineage of devotion. Kunti is one of the great devotees in the epic, whose entire life was shaped by her faith and surrender to the divine. Yudhishthira inherits both the scepter of dharma and the heart of devotion from his mother. In Vedanta, the 'endless victory' — anantavijaya — is the only true victory: the victory of the Self over the illusion of separation. All other victories are temporary. Only the recognition of the infinite Ātman constitutes ananta-vijaya.
commentary.yogananda: The five Pandava brothers and their respective conches form a complete quintet of spiritual faculties. Yudhishthira — the dharmic will — blows 'Anantavijaya,' endless victory, because the force of dharma, properly understood, can never be finally defeated. Nakula's 'Sughoṣa' — beautiful sound — represents the power of harmonious aesthetic perception aligned with the Divine. Sahadeva's 'Maṇipuṣpaka' — jewel and flower — represents the faculty of wisdom and discrimination (Sahadeva was the most learned of the Pandavas in the sacred sciences). Together, these five instruments create a complete sacred symphony of the soul's forces declaring readiness.
commentary.goyandka: This verse continues the enumeration of Pandava conches, now listing the remaining three brothers. 'Anantavijaya' — eternal/endless victory — is aptly named for Yudhishthira, since victory for him is not merely military but dharmic: the establishment of eternal right order. Nakula and Sahadeva are mentioned together with their conches given in the dual form — a grammatical elegance that reflects their closeness as the youngest pair, born of Mādrī (Pāṇḍu's second wife). The naming of conches was not mere convention; each conch was considered a living presence with its own power and resonance. The enumeration of five Pandava conches against the one Kaurava conch (Bhishma's) emphasizes the spiritual richness of the Pandava side.

unconquered / invincible / one who has never been defeated — epithet of Satyaki

commentary.dadaji: Shikhandi's inclusion in this list carries tremendous narrative weight. Born Ambā in a previous life, who had been wronged by Bhishma, reborn as Śikhaṇḍī — this warrior embodies the inexorable working of karma across lifetimes. Dadaji saw in Śikhaṇḍī's presence on the battlefield a reminder that the consequences of our actions toward others do not simply dissolve; they take form, they return, they find their resolution. Bhishma, the most invincible warrior alive, would fall not to any military power but to the karmic force embodied in Śikhaṇḍī. This is the Geeta's background teaching: no one escapes the law of karma, however powerful they may be.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Sātyaki — described here as 'aparājita,' the unconquered — was Krishna's beloved disciple and the most loyal of Arjuna's companions in battle. His epithet 'unconquered' is worth reflecting upon from a Vedantic perspective: the truly unconquered is not the warrior who has never lost a physical battle, but the one who has conquered the internal enemies of desire, anger, and ego. The external invincibility of these warriors is a shadow of the inner invincibility that comes from established Self-knowledge. The Geeta will eventually teach that the one truly 'aparājita' — never conquered — is the Ātman itself, beyond birth, death, sword and spear.
commentary.yogananda: These warriors — Kāśya, Śikhaṇḍī, Dhṛṣṭadyumna, Virāṭa, Sātyaki — represent specific qualities of the spiritually aligned psyche arrayed for battle. The king of Kāśī (Varanasi, city of light and liberation) represents the power of sacred knowledge deployed in action. Śikhaṇḍī, who transcended gender and was reborn for a specific dharmic purpose, represents the power of resolute divine intention that persists across multiple lifetimes. Sātyaki — the unconquered — represents the aspect of consciousness that remains utterly pure and untouched regardless of circumstances, the witness-self that cannot be defeated because it was never in the battle to begin with.
commentary.goyandka: Verses 17 and 18 together form a continuous enumeration of the remaining Pandava commanders who all sounded their conches. The king of Kāśī is unnamed but identified by his title and quality: 'parameṣvāsaḥ' — supreme archer. Śikhaṇḍī's story is one of the most extraordinary in the epic: born as Ambā, rejected by Bhishma and unable to marry, she performed penances, was granted a boon to become male in a future birth, was reborn as Śikhaṇḍī, and ultimately served as the instrument of Bhishma's death. Dhṛṣṭadyumna was born from the sacred fire specifically to kill Droṇa. Sātyaki (also known as Yuyudhāna) was a Yādava hero and Arjuna's student in archery.

verses.sanskrit:
सञ्जय उवाच ।
द्रुपदो द्रौपदेयाश्च सर्वशः पृथिवीपते ।
सौभद्रश्च महाबाहुः शङ्खान्दध्मुः पृथक्पृथक् ॥
verses.transliteration:
sañjaya uvāca
drupado draupadeyāś ca sarvaśaḥ pṛthivī-pate
saubhadraś ca mahā-bāhuḥ śaṅkhān dadhmuḥ pṛthak pṛthak
verses.translation: Sanjaya said: Drupada and the sons of Draupadi — all of them, O lord of earth — and the mighty-armed son of Subhadra (Abhimanyu) blew their conches, each separately.

word_breakdown.meaning: Drupada — king of Panchala, father of Draupadi and Dhrishtadyumna

commentary.dadaji: The phrase 'pṛthak pṛthak' — each separately, each distinctly — is musically and spiritually beautiful. Though they fight on one side for one purpose, each warrior sounds his own conch in his own voice. Dadaji saw in this a lesson about unity in diversity: dharma does not flatten individuals into a uniform force. Each soul has its own note, its own frequency, its own unique contribution to the symphony of righteousness. Abhimanyu — the young, the brilliant, the doomed — sounds his conch here among the greatest warriors. His 'mahā-bāhu' (mighty-armed) epithet signals his power even as the reader who knows the story must feel a pang: this young hero will not survive the war.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Sanjaya addresses Dhritarashtra as 'pṛthivī-pate' — lord of the earth. The irony is sharp: Dhritarashtra, the blind king who holds earthly dominion, cannot see the battlefield he supposedly rules. He depends entirely on Sanjaya's divine vision to witness events. From the Vedantic standpoint, Dhritarashtra is the perfect symbol of avidyā — ignorance — that presides over the realm of the senses (his kingdom) while being constitutionally unable to perceive the real. The blind king is not merely physically blind; he is unable to see the dharmic truth that his attachment to his son has created this catastrophe.
commentary.yogananda: Abhimanyu — the son of Arjuna and Subhadrā, nephew of Krishna — was said to have learned the knowledge of how to enter the seven-layered chakravyūha formation while still in his mother's womb, but the knowledge of how to exit was never completed because Subhadrā fell asleep before Arjuna could finish telling her. This detail — so famous in the Mahabharata — has profound metaphysical resonance. The soul enters the chakravyūha of embodied life with partial knowledge; it must complete that knowledge through lived experience, through the spiritual battle itself. Abhimanyu's eventual entrapment mirrors the aspirant who enters the battle for liberation armed with great capacity but incomplete knowledge.
commentary.goyandka: This verse concludes the enumeration of the Pandava conch-blowers begun in verse 15. 'Sarvaśaḥ' — all of them, every single one — means that the enumeration is now complete; no Pandava commander has been left out. The address 'pṛthivī-pate' to Dhritarashtra is one of several such addresses by Sanjaya throughout the first chapter (others include 'Bhārata,' 'rājan,' etc.), each subtly reminding the blind king that the events being described are the direct consequence of his own failures of governance and justice. 'Pṛthak pṛthak' — each separately — linguistically reinforces what the enumeration demonstrates: the Pandava side has a rich individuality of heroic voices, while the Kaurava side had only one conch explicitly named (Bhishma's).

सञ्जय उवाच ।
स घोषो धार्तराष्ट्राणां हृदयानि व्यदारयत् ।
नभश्च पृथिवीं चैव तुमुलो व्यनुनादयन् ॥
verses.transliteration:
sañjaya uvāca
sa ghoṣo dhārtarāṣṭrāṇāṃ hṛdayāni vyadārayat
nabhaś ca pṛthivīṃ caiva tumulo vyanunādayan
verses.translation: Sanjaya said: That tumultuous sound, reverberating through heaven and earth, rent asunder the hearts of the sons of Dhritarashtra.

of the sons of Dhritarashtra — the Kauravas
the hearts / the inner being (plural — every heart among them)
rent asunder / split apart / shattered (caused them to be split)
tumultuous / overwhelming / terrifying

commentary.dadaji: The sound of the Pandava conches — divine, pure, righteous — literally split the hearts of the Kauravas. Not their bodies: their hearts. Dadaji observed that the sound of dharma is terrifying to those who have chosen adharma. It is not an external weapon that strikes them; it is something within themselves — their own conscience — that responds to the vibration of truth with anguish. The sons of Dhritarashtra knew, in their hearts, that they were wrong. The divine conches gave voice to what they could not silence: the inner knowledge of their own unrighteousness. This is why the sound 'rends the hearts' rather than merely frightening the bodies.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The verse draws a stark contrast: the Kaurava drums filled the sky with noise and bravado; the Pandava conches filled the sky and earth with a sound that 'rent asunder the hearts' of the enemy. This is the power of alignment with truth. A force grounded in dharma does not merely match the power of adharma — it strikes at a deeper level. From the Vedantic perspective, the 'hṛdaya' — the heart — is the seat of consciousness, the cave of the Ātman. When truth sounds its note, it reverberates into that cave and disturbs the false self that has made its home there. The Kauravas are undone not by superior weapons but by the resonance of righteousness.
commentary.yogananda: The divine sound — 'sa ghoṣaḥ' — that fills heaven and earth and rends the hearts of the Kauravas is symbolically the primal sound of Oṃ, the cosmic vibration that underlies all creation. When the soul, guided by the Divine, sounds its authentic note, it has the power to shake the foundations of the ego's kingdom. Yogananda taught that the practice of Oṃ meditation — listening to and merging with the cosmic sound — is itself a preparation for the inner war. The ego cannot stand against the resonance of Oṃ. It 'vyadārayat' — cracks open — in the presence of the primal divine vibration, and in that opening, the light of Self-knowledge begins to enter.
commentary.goyandka: This verse provides the narrative result of the Pandava conch-sounding: the uproar was so immense that it filled 'nabhaś ca pṛthivīṃ ca' — heaven and earth alike — and its effect was specific: it 'vyadārayat hṛdayāni dhārtarāṣṭrāṇām' — it rent asunder the hearts of the Dhārtarāṣṭras. Classical commentators note that this effect is not physical but psychological: the Kaurava army, upon hearing the disciplined and powerful response of the Pandava side, felt demoralization at the deepest level. The word 'vyadārayat' (from vi + √dṝ) conveys a complete splitting — not a crack but a rupture. This moment signals that before a single arrow is fired, the psychological advantage has already shifted to the Pandava side.

सञ्जय उवाच ।

pravṛtte śastra-sampāte dhanur udyamya pāṇḍavaḥ

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna raises his bow — but notice: he does not yet fire. He sees, he surveys, he prepares. Dadaji always emphasized that this moment of pause — of 'dṛṣṭvā,' of seeing before acting — is the moment of conscience. Most people in Arjuna's position, trained warriors with dharmic cause and divine backing, would fire immediately. Arjuna pauses. He looks. And what he is about to see will change everything. The emblem on his flag — Hanuman, the supreme devotee — is profoundly significant. Hanuman reminds us that the greatest strength is not military power but devotion: the capacity to serve the divine will rather than one's own ego. Arjuna's banner carries this message even as his hands prepare for war.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The epithet 'kapi-dhvajaḥ' — he whose banner bears the monkey, i.e., Hanuman — is theologically rich. Hanuman, the divine servant, is the embodiment of Bhakti (devotion) and Karma Yoga (selfless service). His presence on Arjuna's banner declares the spirit in which the warrior fights: not for personal glory but as an instrument of the divine. This is the secret teaching embedded in a single compound word. Before the famous dialogue of the Geeta begins, before Arjuna's crisis, before Krishna's teaching — the answer is already there on Arjuna's flag: act as Hanuman acted, in total surrender to the Divine, and the battle becomes worship.
commentary.yogananda: Hanuman on Arjuna's flag is not accidental. When Arjuna encountered Hanuman during the Mahabharata narrative, Hanuman promised to sit on his chariot flag and give him strength and protection. Yogananda saw in this a profound metaphysical truth: when the individual soul (Arjuna) invites the devotee-consciousness — the consciousness that is fully surrendered to God — it gains a protector and a power that no enemy can overcome. 'Kapi-dhvaja' — the banner of the devoted servant — is the consciousness that Arjuna carries into battle. It is the consciousness the Geeta will ultimately call him to inhabit fully: Naiṣkarmya Karma Yoga, action performed without ego, in total offering.
commentary.goyandka: This verse marks the crucial narrative pivot: Arjuna, positioned in the chariot, sees the Kaurava army arrayed for battle and raises his bow. The locative absolute 'pravṛtte śastra-sampāte' — when the weapons were about to fly — establishes the urgency: this is the last possible moment before battle is joined. Arjuna's epithet 'kapi-dhvaja' refers to the boon obtained from Hanuman, who blessed Arjuna and promised to dwell on his battle standard, multiplying his chariot's power and filling the enemy with dread. 'Dhanur udyamya' — having raised the bow — is the action that precedes the sudden crisis: Arjuna lifts Gāṇḍīva but what he sees next will cause his arms to tremble and his bow to slip.

verses.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच ।
सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये रथं स्थापय मेऽच्युत ।
यावदेतान्निरीक्षेऽहं योद्धुकामानवस्थितान् ॥

arjuna uvāca
senayor ubhayor madhye rathaṃ sthāpaya me 'cyuta
yāvad etān nirīkṣe 'haṃ yoddhu-kāmān avasthitān
verses.translation: Arjuna said: O Achyuta (the Infallible), place my chariot between the two armies so that I may observe those who stand here eager to fight.

Achyuta — the Infallible, the Immovable; one who does not slip or fall — a name of Krishna

commentary.dadaji: Here Arjuna speaks for the first time in the Geeta, and his first act is to ask Krishna to place the chariot in the middle — between the two sides. This is a gesture of profound significance: he wants to see both. He wants to be centered. Dadaji saw this as Arjuna's dharmic instinct asserting itself even before his great crisis: he is not simply charging forward; he pauses to witness fully. He addresses Krishna as 'Acyuta' — the Infallible, the One who never slips. This name, chosen consciously or unconsciously, is the voice of trust: 'You who never slip, guide me.' Every true devotee, at the threshold of life's greatest battles, turns to the Divine and makes this same request.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Arjuna's request to be placed in the center — 'senayor ubhayor madhye' — between both armies — is symbolically the request of every sincere seeker: place me at the point of maximum clarity, where I can see the full truth. The middle position is the witness position — the place of the sākṣī, the observer, who is neither wholly absorbed in one side nor the other. It is also, profoundly, the position from which the truth becomes unbearable and wisdom becomes necessary. Arjuna asks to see 'yoddhu-kāmān' — those eager to fight. He wants to understand the nature of his opponents. This seeing will be the genesis of his crisis — and ultimately of his liberation.
commentary.yogananda: The name 'Acyuta' — the Infallible — is Arjuna's first words to Krishna in the Geeta. Yogananda observed that this name reveals the spiritual relationship between them: Arjuna knows, intuitively, that Krishna will not lead him astray. He may not yet understand everything Krishna will teach, but he trusts utterly. This trust — the capacity to say 'Acyuta, place me where I need to be' — is the beginning of discipleship. The disciple who says to the guru, 'position me correctly, I will look at what you show me' — even if what they see will shatter them — has taken the first step on the path that ends in liberation. Arjuna's request is a model of perfect surrender.
commentary.goyandka: With 'arjuna uvāca' — Arjuna spoke — the Geeta's central voice enters for the first time. Verses 21–22 form a single complete statement of request; they are sometimes read as one unit (21–23 in some recensions). Arjuna asks Krishna — here called 'Acyuta' (the Infallible, one of the 108 names of Viṣṇu) — to place the chariot 'senayor ubhayor madhye' — in the middle space between both armies. The purpose is explicitly stated: 'yāvad etān nirīkṣe' — so that I may thoroughly survey — specifically 'yoddhu-kāmān avasthitān' — those who stand there eager to fight. This is a military commander's reconnaissance, but it will immediately transform into a profound spiritual crisis.

dhārtarāṣṭrasya durbuddher yuddhe priya-cikīrṣavaḥ

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna's second utterance reveals his clarity about the moral situation: those arrayed against him are 'priya-cikīrṣavaḥ' — those who want to please Duryodhana, 'durbuddheḥ' — the evil-minded. He has no illusions about who Duryodhana is or what this war is about. And yet — in just a few verses — when he actually sees who these people are, his moral clarity will collapse into grief. This is the human condition: we can state the right principle clearly in the abstract, but when the faces of loved ones fill the field, principle meets feeling and the battle within begins. The Geeta's genius is that it does not skip this collapse; it enters it fully, and shows us the way through.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The word 'durbuddheḥ' — of the evil-minded one — is Arjuna's own judgment of Duryodhana, spoken before the famous crisis of compassion. He knows who the enemy is. He knows who is responsible for this war. Yet Advaita Vedanta teaches that knowing the situation clearly at the level of the intellect is not the same as being free from attachment. One can correctly assess a situation — 'this is adharma, that is the cause, these are the consequences' — and still be unable to act freely, because the heart remains bound by love, by memory, by the unbearable reality of kinship. The Geeta takes Arjuna from correct intellectual assessment through the furnace of grief to the freedom of realized Self-knowledge.
commentary.yogananda: The desiderative compound 'priya-cikīrṣavaḥ' — those who are eager to please, who desire to gratify — is a profound characterization. Those who have gathered on the Kaurava side are not simply warriors: they are servants of desire, men whose actions are oriented toward pleasing a worldly master rather than serving dharma or the Divine. Yogananda saw in this the definition of samsāric action: acting to please the ego (personal or another's) rather than acting in alignment with one's divine nature. The entire teaching of the Geeta aims to shift Arjuna — and through him, every reader — from 'priya-cikīrṣu' (one who acts to please) to 'nimitta-mātra' (an instrument of the Divine).
commentary.goyandka: This verse completes Arjuna's two-verse request (verses 21–22) to Krishna. The request is specific: he wants to see 'yotsyamānān' — those who are about to fight — particularly those gathered to do what is dear to 'dhārtarāṣṭrasya durbuddheḥ' — Duryodhana, characterized directly as 'evil-minded.' The compound 'priya-cikīrṣavaḥ' uses the desiderative form of √kṛ — they are not merely acting but are eager, desirous to please. This characterizes the Kaurava allies as followers of personal loyalty rather than of principle. The stage is now perfectly set: the chariot will be placed in the center, Arjuna will look, and the great crisis of the Geeta will begin.

commentary.dadaji: Krishna obeys. This is worth pausing over: the Supreme Lord, the source of all creation, immediately fulfills His devotee's request without argument or delay. Dadaji often reflected on how Krishna's compliance here is itself a teaching. God does not force the soul toward wisdom; He positions it where wisdom can arise naturally. Krishna drives the chariot — the finest chariot, drawn by divine white horses — directly between both armies, placing Arjuna before the very faces of Bhishma and Drona, and says simply: 'See, Arjuna. See all the Kurus assembled.' No commentary, no preparation, no warning. Just: look. The instruction to behold is the beginning of all spiritual awakening. Before any word of wisdom can be received, one must be willing to see what is actually there.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The Sanskrit tradition records that Krishna positioned the chariot 'bhīṣma-droṇa-pramukhataḥ' — directly in front of Bhishma and Drona — as if deliberately placing Arjuna before those he loves and reveres most. Sarvapriyananda often pointed to this as divine pedagogical precision: the crisis of detachment cannot be manufactured in the abstract; it must arise from confronting the actual. The command 'paśya' — behold — is an imperative: not a suggestion but a direct instruction from the inner Guru to the disciple. And what one sees when one truly looks — without avoidance, without prejudice — is the source of all genuine spiritual inquiry. Arjuna must see these people as they are, as what they mean to him, before he can hear what they truly are.
commentary.yogananda: In the inner reading of the Geeta, Krishna's positioning of the chariot between the armies represents a moment of supreme clarity of witness-consciousness. The chariot of the body-mind is placed at the exact center — between the forces of past karma and the forces of future aspiration, between the desires pulling back and the dharma calling forward. Yogananda taught that every genuine meditator reaches such a moment: poised between two armies of inner forces, compelled to look at them clearly. Krishna's words 'paśya etān Kurūn' — behold these Kurus — are the inner voice of the Self saying: stop, look, do not flinch. The seeing itself, if complete, carries the seed of liberation.
commentary.goyandka: This verse is pivotal structurally: it ends Arjuna's request (verses 21–22) and begins the fulfillment that will trigger his crisis. Sanjaya describes Krishna — addressed elsewhere as Hṛṣīkeśa and Govinda — as the perfect charioteer who positions the vehicle exactly as requested. 'Bhīṣma-droṇa-pramukhataḥ' specifies the precise positioning: facing Bhishma and Drona specifically, the two most revered elders on the Kaurava side, the two who would be most devastating for Arjuna to fight. The command 'paśya' — behold — is in the imperative, spoken with quiet authority. Classical commentators note that this word echoes through the entire Geeta: see clearly, see the real, and the illusion cannot survive.

commentary.dadaji: The word 'apaśyat' — he saw — marks the great turning. Arjuna looked, and what he saw was not an enemy: it was his family. The list is exhaustive and devastating: fathers, grandfathers, teachers, maternal uncles, brothers, sons, grandsons, friends. Every relationship that constitutes a human life is represented on this battlefield. Dadaji always said that this verse is the truest description of our own inner war: when we sit to examine our lives, when we pause at the threshold of transformation, we see that what we must let go of is not some abstract enemy but everything we love. The spiritual battlefield is always personal. It is always composed of faces we recognize and cherish.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The enumeration in this verse — pitṝn, pitāmahān, ācāryān, mātulān, bhrātṝn, putrān, pautrān, sakhīn — covers seven distinct categories of relationship. This is not casual description; it is a complete map of the relational self. The 'Arjuna' of this verse is every human being who has ever stood at the edge of necessary action and seen that all his reasons to hesitate have human faces. From the Vedantic standpoint, the 'kṣetra' — the field — that Arjuna surveys is precisely the field of the ego's investments: these relationships are the material out of which the false self is constructed. To see them clearly, assembled together, is the first shock of disidentification.
commentary.yogananda: The imperfect tense 'apaśyat' — he was seeing — implies a continued, dawning vision rather than a single glance. Arjuna did not survey the field and move on; he looked and kept looking, and as he looked, the faces became more and more distinct, more and more personal. Yogananda taught that this is exactly the experience of the sincere meditator who, having silenced the mind enough to see clearly, begins to perceive the full depth of their worldly attachments. The practice does not reduce attachment by obscuring its object; it reveals the object more clearly, and in that clarity, the natural question arises: is this worth more than liberation? That question is the beginning of true renunciation.
commentary.goyandka: Verses 24 and 25 together describe the crucial moment when Arjuna, positioned between the armies by Krishna, begins to see. The imperfect 'apaśyat' indicates an ongoing act of perception — he was seeing, taking in, recognizing face after face. The list of relationships is arranged in roughly descending order of seniority: pitṝn (fathers/paternal elders), pitāmahān (grandfathers), ācāryān (teachers — particularly Droṇa and Kṛpācārya), mātulān (maternal uncles — particularly Śalya and Śakuni), bhrātṝn (brothers — the hundred Kauravas), putrān (sons — his own sons fighting on either side), pautrān (grandsons), and sakhīn (friends, companions). The comprehensiveness of the list is deliberate: no human relationship has been left off the battlefield.

commentary.dadaji: The verse concludes with Arjuna 'samīkṣya' — having fully surveyed — all these kinsmen standing before him, and then comes the great wave: kṛpayā — compassion, grief, overwhelming tenderness. Dadaji would often say that this moment is the most human moment in all of sacred scripture. Arjuna is not a coward, not a weakling; he is the greatest warrior of his age. But he is also a man with a heart, and his heart sees clearly what his warrior's mind had perhaps too easily categorized as 'the enemy.' The compassion that overwhelms him here is not wrong — it is beautiful, it is human. The Geeta does not condemn this compassion; it will eventually deepen and purify it, transforming attachment-compassion into the compassion of the liberated sage.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The word 'kṛpayā' — by compassion / by grief — that overtakes Arjuna requires careful interpretation. The Sanskrit root 'kṛp' carries both compassion and lamentation; this is not the impersonal compassion of an enlightened being (karuṇā) but the grief of attachment. Vedanta distinguishes sharply between these two: the compassion of the jñānī, which arises from recognizing the Self in all beings, is liberating; the 'kṛpā' of the ajñānī, which arises from identifying with body and relationship, is binding. Arjuna's crisis is precisely the crisis of this binding compassion — beautiful, genuine, but rooted in a misidentification of what these people truly are. The Geeta will not destroy this compassion; it will transform it by correcting the misidentification.
commentary.yogananda: The gerund 'samīkṣya' — having thoroughly, completely seen — is the hinge of the entire Geeta. Arjuna does not look superficially; he truly sees. And it is the fullness of his seeing that produces the crisis. Yogananda taught that half-hearted spiritual investigation produces only half-hearted results. The seeker who truly meditates, who truly looks at the nature of the self and its attachments, will inevitably encounter Arjuna's experience: the full weight of everything that is held dear, assembled and demanding an answer. The question is not 'will you fight?' — the question is 'who are you?' And until that question is answered by direct experience rather than by doctrine, the warrior must wait in the space of compassion and grief.
commentary.goyandka: This verse completes the survey passage begun in verse 24 and brings us to the emotional precipice: 'tān samīkṣya sa kaunteyaḥ sarvān bandhūn avasthitān' — Arjuna, having fully surveyed all those kinsmen standing there. The word 'sarvān' — all — is emphatic: not a few faces, not isolated relatives, but the entirety of his relational world, assembled for mutual destruction. The address 'kaunteyaḥ' — son of Kunti — is significant: it links Arjuna to his mother, the embodiment of devotion and sacrifice, reminding us of the depth of his humanity. What follows — kṛpayā viṣīdann — is the clinical description of the onset of depression and grief: the collapse of the warrior's resolve in the face of overwhelming personal loss.

commentary.dadaji: Now Arjuna speaks directly to Krishna — 'O Krishna' — and for the first time in the Geeta, addresses the Lord by His most intimate and beloved name. Not Acyuta the Infallible, not Hṛṣīkeśa the Master of Senses — but Krishna. The familiar name of love and childhood. And what does he say? My body is collapsing. My mouth is dry. The physical symptoms of grief and shock are described with clinical precision: 'gātrāṇi sīdanti' — the limbs are sinking, giving way — 'mukhaṃ pariśuṣyati' — the mouth dries up. Dadaji would say: before the Geeta's wisdom can be received, the warrior must fall. The ground must be cleared of arrogance, of certainty, of the comfortable belief that one knows what to do. The drying of the mouth is the silencing of all the answers that were ready before the question was truly asked.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The physical symptoms Arjuna describes are the classical symptoms of what modern psychology calls acute stress response: the failure of gross motor function, the drying of mucous membranes. But the Geeta is not offering a medical case history; it is mapping the soul's experience at the threshold of genuine transformation. 'Gātrāṇi sīdanti' — the limbs fail — means the entire apparatus of action, the karmendriyas, can no longer function. The body refuses to carry out the will's commands. This is significant: the failure is not merely intellectual doubt or emotional distress — the very capacity for action has broken down. This is the condition that makes the teaching of the Geeta both necessary and possible. Only when action is impossible does the question of the Self become urgent.
commentary.yogananda: The body's response — limbs failing, mouth drying — is nature's way of forcing a halt. Yogananda described this experience in terms of prāṇa: the vital energy that normally flows outward into action has suddenly reversed, turned inward, as the soul confronts a situation its ordinary resources cannot handle. The drying of the mouth is particularly telling: the mouth is the organ of speech, of assertion, of declaration. When it dries, the usual self-confident voice falls silent. In that silence — the silence of failed certainty — the voice of the inner Guru, Krishna, can for the first time be truly heard. The crisis of verse 26 is not the problem the Geeta must solve; it is the necessary condition that makes the Geeta's teaching possible.
commentary.goyandka: With 'arjuna uvāca' — Arjuna spoke — the great lamentation section of the first chapter begins. Arjuna addresses Krishna — using the personal name 'Kṛṣṇa' rather than a formal epithet — and describes the onset of physical breakdown in response to the sight of his kinsmen. Classical Indian medicine (Āyurveda) identifies these symptoms — failure of limbs, drying of the mouth — as the effects of extreme grief and vāta-imbalance caused by emotional shock. The Geeta's first chapter uses this detailed physiological description to ground the spiritual crisis in bodily reality: this is not philosophy in the abstract but suffering in the flesh. The desiderative 'yuyutsum' — those eager to fight — applied to his own people, captures the unbearable irony: those he loves most are precisely those most eager to destroy each other.

commentary.dadaji: The Gāṇḍīva slips. This is the detail that would have stunned any listener in the ancient world: this bow was a divine gift, the most powerful weapon in the world, and Arjuna had spent his entire life in union with it — it was an extension of his very identity as a warrior. And it slips from his hand. Dadaji saw in this the profound teaching that when the soul is in genuine crisis, all its acquired instruments of mastery become useless. The bow of skill, of training, of worldly competence falls away. This is not weakness — it is the necessary dispossession that precedes true knowledge. The burning skin and standing hair are nature's testimony that something far greater than a military decision is happening: a soul is being broken open.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The hair standing on end — 'roma-harṣaḥ' — is a physiological response associated in the Sanskrit tradition with both terror and extreme devotion. The same response occurs in the accounts of great saints and bhaktas in the presence of the Divine. This ambiguity is significant: Arjuna's experience, while on the surface a crisis of grief and fear, contains within it the seed of bhakti — the trembling before something immeasurably greater than oneself. Vedanta teaches that grief and love are two faces of the same depth of feeling; it is the direction — attachment or surrender — that determines whether the same intensity leads to bondage or liberation. The Gāṇḍīva falling marks the end of self-reliance; something greater must now be picked up.
commentary.yogananda: The Gāṇḍīva — Arjuna's divine bow — was given to him by Agni, the fire-god, at the burning of the Khāṇḍava forest. It is a symbol of Arjuna's spiritual power: his capacity for one-pointed concentration, his will refined through years of tapas and practice. When this bow slips from his hand, it means that the concentrated spiritual will has momentarily failed — not permanently, not irreversibly, but completely in this moment. Yogananda saw this as the experience of the advanced meditator who, after long and dedicated practice, suddenly encounters a spiritual obstacle that their accumulated techniques cannot resolve. The skin burning ('paridahyate') is the sensation of prāṇic overwhelm — too much force passing through a system not yet prepared to channel it.
commentary.goyandka: The physical symptoms continue to accumulate in clinical detail: vepathu (bodily trembling), roma-harṣa (goosebumps/horripilation), the slipping of Gāṇḍīva, and the burning of the skin. Each symptom corresponds to a classical Indian medical and Āyurvedic description of extreme grief and psychological breakdown. But the detail of Gāṇḍīva slipping deserves special attention. In the Mahābhārata, this bow was obtained by Agni through the great burning of the Khāṇḍava forest; it was the bow of Varuṇa; it could release ten thousand arrows simultaneously; it had never before slipped from Arjuna's grip. Its falling is therefore not merely physical weakness but the dissolution of the warrior identity itself. The instrument of Arjuna's greatness can no longer be held.
